question: Q.71) Developing countries have often experienced mixed outcomes from globalisation. Which of the following is a potential disadvantage of globalisation for developing economies?

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- While globalisation can lead to overall economic growth, its benefits may not be shared equally. It often benefits skilled labor and capital owners more than unskilled labor, whose jobs might be threatened by foreign competition or automation. This can lead to a widening gap between the rich and the poor, increasing income inequality within the country.

‚úÖ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à

- ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡§ø ‡§µ‡•à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§ï‡§∞‡§£ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§ï ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ ‡§¶‡•á ‡§∏‡§ï‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•à, ‡§á‡§∏‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§æ‡§≠ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§® ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ù‡§æ ‡§®‡§π‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§ø‡§è ‡§ú‡§æ ‡§∏‡§ï‡§§‡•á ‡§π‡•à‡§Ç‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§Ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∏‡§∞ ‡§Ö‡§ï‡•Å‡§∂‡§≤ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡§®‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∂‡§≤ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§™‡•Ç‡§Ç‡§ú‡•Ä ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ï‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï ‡§≤‡§æ‡§≠ ‡§™‡§π‡•Å‡§Ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•à, ‡§ú‡§ø‡§®‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§®‡•å‡§ï‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡•Ä ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ö‡§æ‡§≤‡§® ‡§∏‡•á ‡§ñ‡§§‡§∞‡§æ ‡§π‡•ã ‡§∏‡§ï‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•à‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§ó‡§∞‡•Ä‡§¨‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•á ‡§¨‡•Ä‡§ö ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§ñ‡§æ‡§à ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§ö‡•å‡§°‡§º‡§æ ‡§ï‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§ï‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•à, ‡§ú‡§ø‡§∏‡§∏‡•á ‡§¶‡•á‡§∂ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≠‡•Ä‡§§‡§∞ ‡§Ü‡§Ø ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§§‡§æ ‡§¨‡§¢‡§º ‡§∏‡§ï‡§§‡•Ä ‡§π‡•à‡•§

- Managing the distributional consequences of globalisation and ensuring inclusive growth is a major policy challenge for developing countries.

- ‡§µ‡•à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§ï‡§∞‡§£ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡§£‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¨‡§Ç‡§ß‡§® ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡§æ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡•Ä ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§∏‡•Å‡§®‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏‡§∂‡•Ä‡§≤ ‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§è‡§ï ‡§¨‡§°‡§º‡•Ä ‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø‡§ó‡§§ ‡§ö‡•Å‡§®‡•å‡§§‡•Ä ‡§π‡•à‡•§
explanation.fact:

- The 'brain drain', where highly skilled professionals from developing countries migrate to developed countries, can be another negative consequence of globalisation.

question: Q.72) Which of the following industries was operational in India at the time of independence?

Correct Answer: Iron and steel industry.

- At the time of independence, India had a very limited industrial base. However, some modern industries had been established, most notably the iron and steel industry. The Tata Iron and Steel Company (TISCO) was established in Jamshedpur in 1907. There were also established cotton textile, jute, sugar, and cement industries.

- ‡§á‡§≤‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§∞‡•â‡§®‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∏, ‡§è‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ã‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡•á‡§∏ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§Ü‡§ß‡•Å‡§®‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ë‡§ü‡•ã‡§Æ‡•ã‡§¨‡§æ‡§á‡§≤ ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§æ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§¨‡§æ‡§¶ ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§ß‡§ø ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§∏‡§ø‡§§ ‡§π‡•Å‡§è, ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑ ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§™‡§Ç‡§ö‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡§®‡§æ‡§ì‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•á ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§î‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•Ä‡§ï‡§∞‡§£ ‡§™‡§∞ ‡§ú‡•ã‡§∞ ‡§¶‡•á‡§®‡•á ‡§ï‡•á ‡§∏‡§æ‡§•‡•§

question: Q.73) How did globalisation affect India's economic growth?

explanation.summary:
Correct Answer: Made it grow faster.

‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞: ‡§á‡§∏‡•á ‡§§‡•á‡§ú‡•Ä ‡§∏‡•á ‡§¨‡§¢‡§º‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡•§
explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- The opening up of the Indian economy through the 1991 reforms led to a significant acceleration in GDP growth. Globalisation facilitated this by increasing access to foreign capital (FDI), modern technology, and new export markets. The increased competition from foreign firms also forced domestic industries to become more efficient and productive. India's average annual GDP growth rate jumped from around 5.7% in the 1980s to over 7-8% in the 2000s.

‚úÖ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à

- 1991 ‡§ï‡•á ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•á ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§ñ‡•Å‡§≤‡§®‡•á ‡§∏‡•á ‡§∏‡§ï‡§≤ ‡§ò‡§∞‡•á‡§≤‡•Ç ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§¶ ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§µ‡•É‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§è‡§ï ‡§Æ‡§π‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§£ ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§£ ‡§π‡•Å‡§Ü‡•§ ‡§µ‡•à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§ï‡§∞‡§£ ‡§®‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡•Ä ‡§™‡•Ç‡§Ç‡§ú‡•Ä (‡§è‡§´‡§°‡•Ä‡§Ü‡§à), ‡§Ü‡§ß‡•Å‡§®‡§ø‡§ï ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•å‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§®‡§è ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§ ‡§¨‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§§‡§ï ‡§™‡§π‡•Å‡§Ç‡§ö ‡§¨‡§¢‡§º‡§æ‡§ï‡§∞ ‡§á‡§∏‡•á ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ó‡§Æ ‡§¨‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡•§ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡•Ä ‡§´‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•á ‡§¨‡§¢‡§º‡•Ä ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ ‡§®‡•á ‡§ò‡§∞‡•á‡§≤‡•Ç ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∂‡§≤ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§ï ‡§¨‡§®‡§®‡•á ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§≠‡•Ä ‡§Æ‡§ú‡§¨‡•Ç‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡•§ ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§ ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§î‡§∏‡§§ ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§°‡•Ä‡§™‡•Ä ‡§µ‡•É‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø ‡§¶‡§∞ 1980 ‡§ï‡•á ‡§¶‡§∂‡§ï ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§≤‡§ó‡§≠‡§ó 5.7% ‡§∏‡•á ‡§¨‡§¢‡§º‡§ï‡§∞ 2000 ‡§ï‡•á ‡§¶‡§∂‡§ï ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç 7-8% ‡§∏‡•á ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï ‡§π‡•ã ‡§ó‡§à‡•§
explanation.analysis_incorrect:
‚ùå Why other options are incorrect

- Globalisation had a profound, not zero, effect on the economy.
- It accelerated growth, not slowed it down or reduced GDP.

‚ùå ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™ ‡§ó‡§≤‡§§ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à‡§Ç

- ‡§µ‡•à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§ï‡§∞‡§£ ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞ ‡§∂‡•Ç‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§®‡§π‡•Ä‡§Ç, ‡§¨‡§≤‡•ç‡§ï‡§ø ‡§ó‡§π‡§∞‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ ‡§™‡§°‡§º‡§æ‡•§
- ‡§á‡§∏‡§®‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§ß‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§®‡§π‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§°‡•Ä‡§™‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§ï‡§Æ ‡§®‡§π‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ, ‡§¨‡§≤‡•ç‡§ï‡§ø ‡§á‡§∏‡•á ‡§§‡•á‡§ú ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡•§
explanation.conclusion:
üìù Concluding Note

- While it came with challenges, globalisation has been a key driver of India's transformation into one of the world's fastest-growing major economies.

üìù ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑

- ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§ö‡•Å‡§®‡•å‡§§‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•á ‡§∏‡§æ‡§• ‡§Ü‡§Ø‡§æ, ‡§µ‡•à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§ï‡§∞‡§£ ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§¶‡•Å‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§∏‡§¨‡§∏‡•á ‡§§‡•á‡§ú‡•Ä ‡§∏‡•á ‡§¨‡§¢‡§º‡§§‡•Ä ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§ì‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•á ‡§è‡§ï ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§® ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§è‡§ï ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ ‡§ö‡§æ‡§≤‡§ï ‡§∞‡§π‡§æ ‡§π‡•à‡•§

question: Q.74) What was the reason for stagnation in the agricultural sector during the colonial rule?
options: Establishment of large scale industries by the colonial government
Extreme commercialisation of agriculture by the colonial government
Imposition of high taxes on the food grains and cash crops by the colonial government
Various systems of land settlement that were introduced by the colonial government
correct: Various systems of land settlement that were introduced by the colonial government

explanation.summary:
Correct Answer: Various systems of land settlement that were introduced by the colonial government.

‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞: ‡§î‡§™‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï ‡§∏‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ ‡§∂‡•Å‡§∞‡•Ç ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§ó‡§à ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§® ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§ø ‡§¨‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ã‡§¨‡§∏‡•ç‡§§ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡§æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Å‡•§
explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- The primary cause of agricultural stagnation was the exploitative land revenue systems introduced by the British, such as the Zamindari, Ryotwari, and Mahalwari systems. These systems were designed to maximize revenue extraction for the colonial state. They led to exorbitant rents, insecurity of tenure for the actual cultivators, and the rise of a class of absentee landlords, all of which destroyed the incentive and the means for farmers to invest in agricultural improvements.

‚úÖ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à

- ‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡§ø ‡§†‡§π‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§•‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£ ‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§ú‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ ‡§∂‡•Å‡§∞‡•Ç ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§ó‡§à ‡§∂‡•ã‡§∑‡§ï ‡§≠‡•Ç-‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡§æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Å ‡§•‡•Ä‡§Ç, ‡§ú‡•à‡§∏‡•á ‡§ï‡§ø ‡§ú‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§Ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä, ‡§∞‡•à‡§Ø‡§§‡§µ‡§æ‡§°‡§º‡•Ä ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§≤‡§µ‡§æ‡§°‡§º‡•Ä ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡§æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Å‡•§ ‡§á‡§® ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡§æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§î‡§™‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§£ ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§§‡§Æ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡•á ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§°‡§ø‡§ú‡§º‡§æ‡§á‡§® ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ó‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§•‡§æ‡•§ ‡§á‡§®‡§∏‡•á ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï ‡§≤‡§ó‡§æ‡§®, ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§§‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤ ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ, ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§™‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ú‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§Ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•á ‡§è‡§ï ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§â‡§¶‡§Ø ‡§π‡•Å‡§Ü, ‡§á‡§® ‡§∏‡§≠‡•Ä ‡§®‡•á ‡§ï‡§ø‡§∏‡§æ‡§®‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡§ø ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§∂ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡•á ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§π‡§® ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§®‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§®‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü ‡§ï‡§∞ ‡§¶‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡•§
explanation.analysis_incorrect:
‚ùå Why other options are incorrect

- While commercialisation of agriculture and high taxes (Options 2 & 3) were also contributing factors, they were themselves consequences of the underlying land settlement systems. The land systems were the foundational cause.
- The colonial government did not establish large scale industries; in fact, it presided over de-industrialization.

‚ùå ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™ ‡§ó‡§≤‡§§ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à‡§Ç

question: Q.75) What percentage of the Indian population was dependent on agriculture around the time of independence?

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- At the time of independence in 1947, the Indian economy was predominantly agrarian. Historical estimates consistently show that a vast majority of the country's workforce was engaged in agriculture and allied activities. The figure is generally cited to be in the range of 70% to 75%.

question: Q.76) Which of the following was a major criticism of the Green Revolution in India?
options: It led to regional and crop imbalances.
correct: It led to regional and crop imbalances.

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- A major criticism of the Green Revolution is that its benefits were not evenly distributed. 
- **Regional Imbalance:** It was most successful in states that already had better infrastructure like irrigation (Punjab, Haryana, Western UP), thus increasing regional disparities.
- **Crop Imbalance:** It focused heavily on wheat and rice, while the production of other important crops like pulses and coarse grains stagnated, leading to an imbalance in the cropping pattern.

‚úÖ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à

- ‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§è‡§ï ‡§¨‡§°‡§º‡•Ä ‡§Ü‡§≤‡•ã‡§ö‡§®‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§π‡•à ‡§ï‡§ø ‡§á‡§∏‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§æ‡§≠ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§® ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡§ø‡§§ ‡§®‡§π‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§π‡•Å‡§è‡•§
- **‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§Ç‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡§®:** ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§â‡§® ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§¨‡§∏‡•á ‡§∏‡§´‡§≤ ‡§∞‡§π‡§æ ‡§ú‡§π‡§æ‡§Å ‡§™‡§π‡§≤‡•á ‡§∏‡•á ‡§π‡•Ä ‡§¨‡•á‡§π‡§§‡§∞ ‡§¨‡•Å‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä ‡§¢‡§æ‡§Å‡§ö‡§æ ‡§ú‡•à‡§∏‡•á ‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§à (‡§™‡§Ç‡§ú‡§æ‡§¨, ‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£‡§æ, ‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§Ø‡•Ç‡§™‡•Ä) ‡§•‡§æ, ‡§ú‡§ø‡§∏‡§∏‡•á ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§§‡§æ‡§è‡§Å ‡§¨‡§¢‡§º‡•Ä‡§Ç‡•§
- **‡§´‡§∏‡§≤ ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§Ç‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡§®:** ‡§á‡§∏‡§®‡•á ‡§ó‡•á‡§π‡•Ç‡§Ç ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§ö‡§æ‡§µ‡§≤ ‡§™‡§∞ ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§® ‡§ï‡•á‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ, ‡§ú‡§¨‡§ï‡§ø ‡§¶‡§æ‡§≤‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§ü‡•á ‡§Ö‡§®‡§æ‡§ú ‡§ú‡•à‡§∏‡•Ä ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡§π‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§£ ‡§´‡§∏‡§≤‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§® ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§∞ ‡§π‡•ã ‡§ó‡§Ø‡§æ, ‡§ú‡§ø‡§∏‡§∏‡•á ‡§´‡§∏‡§≤ ‡§™‡•à‡§ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§® ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§Ç‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡§® ‡§™‡•à‡§¶‡§æ ‡§π‡•ã ‡§ó‡§Ø‡§æ‡•§
explanation.analysis_incorrect:
‚ùå Why other options are incorrect

- It promoted chemical-intensive farming (fertilizers, pesticides), not organic farming.
- It dramatically increased, not reduced, agricultural output.
- It was based on the adoption of modern technology (HYV seeds, machinery), not its discouragement.

‚ùå ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™ ‡§ó‡§≤‡§§ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à‡§Ç

- ‡§á‡§∏‡§®‡•á ‡§ú‡•à‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ñ‡•á‡§§‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§®‡§π‡•Ä‡§Ç, ‡§¨‡§≤‡•ç‡§ï‡§ø ‡§∞‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ø‡§®-‡§ó‡§π‡§® ‡§ñ‡•á‡§§‡•Ä (‡§â‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§ï, ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§ü‡§®‡§æ‡§∂‡§ï) ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§¨‡§¢‡§º‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§¶‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡•§
- ‡§á‡§∏‡§®‡•á ‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡§ø ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§® ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§ï‡§Æ ‡§®‡§π‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ, ‡§¨‡§≤‡•ç‡§ï‡§ø ‡§®‡§æ‡§ü‡§ï‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§¨‡§¢‡§º‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡•§
- ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§Ü‡§ß‡•Å‡§®‡§ø‡§ï ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•å‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø‡§ï‡•Ä (HYV ‡§¨‡•Ä‡§ú, ‡§Æ‡§∂‡•Ä‡§®‡§∞‡•Ä) ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§Ö‡§™‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•á ‡§™‡§∞ ‡§Ü‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§§ ‡§•‡§æ, ‡§® ‡§ï‡§ø ‡§á‡§∏‡§ï‡•á ‡§π‡§§‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§π‡§® ‡§™‡§∞‡•§
explanation.conclusion:
üìù Concluding Note

- While the Green Revolution saved India from famines, its socio-economic and environmental side-effects, including increased inequality and soil degradation, remain a subject of debate.

üìù ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑

- ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡§ø ‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§®‡•á ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§ ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§Ö‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§¨‡§ö‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ, ‡§á‡§∏‡§ï‡•á ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ú‡§ø‡§ï-‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§ï ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§∞‡§£‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ, ‡§ú‡§ø‡§®‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§¨‡§¢‡§º‡•Ä ‡§π‡•Å‡§à ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§§‡§æ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∞‡§£ ‡§∂‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§≤ ‡§π‡•à, ‡§¨‡§π‡§∏ ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Ø ‡§¨‡§®‡•á ‡§π‡•Å‡§è ‡§π‡•à‡§Ç‡•§
explanation.fact:

- The Green Revolution also increased income inequality between large and small farmers, as only the wealthier farmers could afford the expensive inputs required by the new technology.

üí° ‡§∞‡•ã‡§ö‡§ï ‡§§‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø

- ‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§®‡•á ‡§¨‡§°‡§º‡•á ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§õ‡•ã‡§ü‡•á ‡§ï‡§ø‡§∏‡§æ‡§®‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•á ‡§¨‡•Ä‡§ö ‡§Ü‡§Ø ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§§‡§æ ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§≠‡•Ä ‡§¨‡§¢‡§º‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ, ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç‡§ï‡§ø ‡§ï‡•á‡§µ‡§≤ ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§∏‡§æ‡§® ‡§π‡•Ä ‡§®‡§à ‡§§‡§ï‡§®‡•Ä‡§ï ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ ‡§Ü‡§µ‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï ‡§Æ‡§π‡§Ç‡§ó‡•á ‡§á‡§®‡§™‡•Å‡§ü ‡§ñ‡§∞‡•Ä‡§¶ ‡§∏‡§ï‡§§‡•á ‡§•‡•á‡•§

question: Q.77) Which organisation's support was crucial in India's globalisation process post 1991 economic crisis?

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- As India faced a severe Balance of Payments crisis in 1991, it approached the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and the World Bank for financial assistance. The bailout loan from the IMF was provided on the condition that India would undertake a Structural Adjustment Program, which involved liberalising its economy and integrating it with the global economy (i.e., globalisation).

‚úÖ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à

question: Q.78) Colonial policies significantly altered India's trade structure. Which of the following best describes India's foreign trade pattern at the time of independence?
options: Export of raw materials and import of manufactured goods
Export of finished goods and import of raw materials
Export of capital goods and import of consumer goods
Balanced trade between agriculture and industry
correct: Export of raw materials and import of manufactured goods

explanation.summary:
Correct Answer: Export of raw materials and import of manufactured goods.

‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞: ‡§ï‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡•á ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≤ ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≤ ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§Ü‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•§
explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- This question reiterates the classic colonial economic relationship. The British systematically geared the Indian economy to serve as a source of cheap raw materials (like cotton, jute, spices) for its own industries. Simultaneously, India became a captive market for high-priced finished goods (like textiles) manufactured in Britain. This led to the decline of indigenous industries and a drain of wealth from India.

question: Q.79) The main objective of British economic policies in India was to:

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- The overarching goal of all British economic policies in India‚Äîfrom land revenue systems to trade policies to railway construction‚Äîwas to serve the interests of Great Britain. India was treated as a colony whose primary economic function was to supply raw materials, provide a market for British goods, and offer a profitable avenue for British capital investment. This process subordinated the Indian economy to the British economy.

question: Q.80) What was the main objective of India's First Five Year Plan (1951‚Äì56)?

‚úÖ Why this is correct

- The First Five-Year Plan was formulated in the immediate aftermath of independence and partition, a period marked by food shortages and high inflation. Therefore, the plan's overriding priority was to achieve self-sufficiency in food grains and stabilize the economy. It focused on developing the primary sector, with major investments in agriculture, irrigation (like the Bhakra and Hirakud dams), and power projects.

question: Q.81) The Human Development Index emphasises people-centric development. Who is credited with creating the HDI alongside Amartya Sen?

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- The Human Development Index (HDI) was created and launched in 1990 by the Pakistani economist Mahbub ul Haq. He led the team at the UNDP that developed the index and the Human Development Reports. While Nobel laureate Amartya Sen's work on 'capability approach' provided the conceptual foundation for the HDI and he collaborated closely with Haq, Mahbub ul Haq is credited as the primary creator of the index.

question: Q.82) Which of the following is considered a major challenge to human development in India?

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- Despite India's overall progress in human development, a major challenge is the significant disparity in outcomes between different states and regions. States like Kerala and Goa have HDI scores comparable to developed countries, while states in the northern and eastern parts of the country (the 'BIMARU' states) lag far behind in terms of health, education, and standard of living. This uneven development poses a significant challenge to achieving inclusive growth.

- Bridging these regional gaps through targeted policies and investments is crucial for improving India's overall human development index and ensuring that the benefits of growth reach all citizens.

question: Q.83) During the colonial period, the services sector accounted for only ___.

‚úÖ Why this is correct

- The question likely refers to the share of the services sector in total employment. During the colonial period, the Indian economy was overwhelmingly agrarian. The modern services sector (like banking, transport, administration) was very small and catered mainly to colonial interests. Historical estimates suggest that the share of the workforce in the services sector was very low, in the range of 5-10%, reflecting the pre-modern structure of the economy.

question: Q.84) Which of the following sectors employed the largest share of India's population before independence?

‚úÖ Why this is correct

- Before independence, the Indian economy was fundamentally agrarian. The primary sector, dominated by agriculture, was the main source of livelihood for the vast majority of the population. Historical estimates indicate that around 70-75% of the workforce was engaged in agriculture and related activities.

question: Q.85) In which of the following years was the monetary policy framework moved towards flexible inflation targeting and a six member Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) constituted for setting the policy rate?

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- The shift to a formal flexible inflation targeting (FIT) framework was a major monetary policy reform in India. It was operationalized in 2016. This involved amending the RBI Act, 1934, to give the RBI a clear mandate for price stability. As part of this reform, the six-member Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) was constituted in September 2016 to take decisions on the policy repo rate.

‚úÖ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à

- ‡§è‡§ï ‡§î‡§™‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï ‡§≤‡§ö‡•Ä‡§≤‡•á ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§´‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Ä‡§ï‡§∞‡§£ (FIT) ‡§¢‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ö‡•á ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§¨‡§¶‡§≤‡§æ‡§µ ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§è‡§ï ‡§¨‡§°‡§º‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï ‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§•‡§æ‡•§ ‡§á‡§∏‡•á 2016 ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ó‡§Ø‡§æ‡•§ ‡§á‡§∏‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§Ü‡§∞‡§¨‡•Ä‡§Ü‡§à ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Æ, 1934 ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∂‡•ã‡§ß‡§® ‡§ï‡§∞‡§ï‡•á ‡§Ü‡§∞‡§¨‡•Ä‡§Ü‡§à ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§∞‡§§‡§æ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§è‡§ï ‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü ‡§ú‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡•á‡§∂ ‡§¶‡•á‡§®‡§æ ‡§∂‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§≤ ‡§•‡§æ‡•§ ‡§á‡§∏ ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§π‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡•á ‡§ï‡•á ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç, ‡§™‡•â‡§≤‡§ø‡§∏‡•Ä ‡§∞‡•á‡§™‡•ã ‡§¶‡§∞ ‡§™‡§∞ ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§Ø ‡§≤‡•á‡§®‡•á ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§∏‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç‡§¨‡§∞ 2016 ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§õ‡§π ‡§∏‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡•å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï ‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø (‡§è‡§Æ‡§™‡•Ä‡§∏‡•Ä) ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§ó‡§†‡§® ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ó‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§•‡§æ‡•§
explanation.analysis_incorrect:
‚ùå Why other options are incorrect

- The other years are incorrect. While discussions about inflation targeting had been going on for years (notably recommended by the Urjit Patel Committee in 2014), the legal framework and the MPC were established in 2016.

question: Q.86) The government tracks the performance of eight core industries to monitor industrial activity. What is the approximate weight of the core industries in the Index of Industrial Production (IIP)?

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- The Index of Industrial Production (IIP) is a composite indicator that measures the short-term changes in the volume of production of a basket of industrial products. Within the IIP, there are eight core industries which are considered the backbone of the industrial sector. These are Coal, Crude Oil, Natural Gas, Refinery Products, Fertilizers, Steel, Cement, and Electricity. Their combined weight in the IIP (with base year 2011-12) is 40.27%. Therefore, 40% is the correct approximation.

question: Q.87) Which of the following options best defines 'Sustainable Development'?
options: Development that meets present needs without compromising future generations
correct: Development that meets present needs without compromising future generations

explanation.summary:
Correct Answer: Development that meets present needs without compromising future generations.

‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞: ‡§ê‡§∏‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§ú‡•ã ‡§≠‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§™‡•Ä‡§¢‡§º‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•á ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§ù‡•å‡§§‡§æ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§è ‡§¨‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§æ‡§® ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§ú‡§∞‡•Ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡§æ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•à‡•§
explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- This is the most widely accepted and classic definition of sustainable development. It was given by the Brundtland Commission in its 1987 report, 'Our Common Future'. The definition elegantly captures the two core concepts: the concept of 'needs', in particular the essential needs of the world's poor, and the idea of 'limitations' imposed by the state of technology and social organization on the environment's ability to meet present and future needs. It emphasizes inter-generational equity.

‚úÖ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à

- ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§∏‡§§‡§§ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§∏‡§¨‡§∏‡•á ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§ï ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§ï‡•É‡§§ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§≤‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§ï ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§∑‡§æ ‡§π‡•à‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç‡§ü‡§≤‡•à‡§Ç‡§° ‡§Ü‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§™‡§®‡•Ä 1987 ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§ü, '‡§π‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ù‡§æ ‡§≠‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø' ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•Ä ‡§ó‡§à ‡§•‡•Ä‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§∑‡§æ ‡§¶‡•ã ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§æ‡§ì‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§ö‡§ø‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§£ ‡§¢‡§Ç‡§ó ‡§∏‡•á ‡§™‡§ï‡§°‡§º‡§§‡•Ä ‡§π‡•à: '‡§Ü‡§µ‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡§§‡§æ‡§ì‡§Ç' ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§æ, ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑ ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§¶‡•Å‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§ó‡§∞‡•Ä‡§¨‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§Ü‡§µ‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï ‡§Ü‡§µ‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡§§‡§æ‡§è‡§Ç, ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§æ‡§® ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§≠‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§ú‡§∞‡•Ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡§æ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡•á ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§∞‡§£ ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Æ‡§§‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•å‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ú‡§ø‡§ï ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ó‡§†‡§® ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ ‡§≤‡§ó‡§æ‡§à ‡§ó‡§à '‡§∏‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ì‡§Ç' ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§§‡§∞-‡§™‡•Ä‡§¢‡§º‡•Ä‡§ó‡§§ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§§‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞ ‡§ú‡•ã‡§∞ ‡§¶‡•á‡§§‡•Ä ‡§π‡•à‡•§

- The United Nations' 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development includes 17 Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) that provide a shared blueprint for peace and prosperity for people and the planet.

üí° ‡§∞‡•ã‡§ö‡§ï ‡§§‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø

- ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§∏‡§§‡§§ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è 2030 ‡§è‡§ú‡•á‡§Ç‡§°‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç 17 ‡§∏‡§§‡§§ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø (‡§è‡§∏‡§°‡•Ä‡§ú‡•Ä) ‡§∂‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§≤ ‡§π‡•à‡§Ç ‡§ú‡•ã ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ó‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§∂‡§æ‡§Ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•É‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§è‡§ï ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ù‡§æ ‡§ñ‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡§æ‡§® ‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‡•á ‡§π‡•à‡§Ç‡•§

question: Q.88) Which of the following correctly describes the impact of 1991 reforms on agricultural exports?
options: Only wheat and rice were allowed for export.
Export promotion was encouraged through de-regulation.
Export restrictions were imposed to ensure food security.
correct: Export promotion was encouraged through de-regulation.

explanation.summary:
Correct Answer: Export promotion was encouraged through de-regulation.

‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞: ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§®-‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡•á ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§® ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ó‡§Ø‡§æ‡•§
explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- As part of the broader trade liberalisation policy of 1991, the government moved to de-regulate agricultural trade. This involved removing quantitative restrictions (like export bans and quotas) on many agricultural products and reducing export duties. The aim was to promote exports, integrate Indian agriculture with the world market, and ensure that Indian farmers could benefit from higher international prices.

question: Q.90) Which of the following indicators is NOT directly included in the calculation of the Human Development Index (HDI)?

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- The HDI is calculated based on three dimensions and four indicators:
  1. **A long and healthy life:** Measured by Life expectancy at birth.
  2. **Knowledge:** Measured by Mean years of schooling and Expected years of schooling.
  3. **A decent standard of living:** Measured by Gross National Income (GNI) per capita (PPP $).
While the Infant Mortality Rate (IMR) is a very important indicator of health and overall development, it is not one of the direct components used to calculate the HDI composite score.

question: Q.91) Which of the following sectors has been classified as infrastructure by the Government of India for improved financing access?

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- The Government of India maintains a Harmonised Master List of Infrastructure Sub-sectors. Granting 'infrastructure' status to a sector makes it eligible for certain benefits, such as easier access to long-term credit from banks and financial institutions, and eligibility for foreign direct investment. Warehousing, including cold storage and logistics parks, has been granted infrastructure status to strengthen the agricultural supply chain and reduce post-harvest losses.

- ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§ ‡§∏‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∞‡§ö‡§®‡§æ ‡§â‡§™-‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§è‡§ï ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ó‡§§ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§ü‡§∞ ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ö‡•Ä ‡§∞‡§ñ‡§§‡•Ä ‡§π‡•à‡•§ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§∏‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•ã '‡§¨‡•Å‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä ‡§¢‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ö‡•á' ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡§æ ‡§¶‡•á‡§®‡•á ‡§∏‡•á ‡§µ‡§π ‡§ï‡•Å‡§õ ‡§≤‡§æ‡§≠‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§π‡•ã ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•à, ‡§ú‡•à‡§∏‡•á ‡§ï‡§ø ‡§¨‡•à‡§Ç‡§ï‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•á ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§ò‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ã‡§£ ‡§§‡§ï ‡§Ü‡§∏‡§æ‡§® ‡§™‡§π‡•Å‡§Ç‡§ö, ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡•Ä ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§∂ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§æ‡•§ ‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡§ø ‡§Ü‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•É‡§Ç‡§ñ‡§≤‡§æ ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§ú‡§¨‡•Ç‡§§ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡•á ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§ü‡§æ‡§à ‡§ï‡•á ‡§¨‡§æ‡§¶ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§®‡•Å‡§ï‡§∏‡§æ‡§® ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§ï‡§Æ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡•á ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§ï‡•ã‡§≤‡•ç‡§° ‡§∏‡•ç‡§ü‡•ã‡§∞‡•á‡§ú ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§≤‡•â‡§ú‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∏ ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ï ‡§∏‡§π‡§ø‡§§ ‡§µ‡•á‡§Ø‡§∞‡§π‡§æ‡§â‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ó ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§¨‡•Å‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä ‡§¢‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ö‡•á ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡§æ ‡§¶‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ó‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§π‡•à‡•§

question: Q.92) In the first phase of the Green Revolution (approximately mid 1960s upto mid 1970s), the use of HYV seeds was restricted to the more affluent states such as
options: Punjab, Andhra Pradesh and Tamil Nadu
correct: Punjab, Andhra Pradesh and Tamil Nadu

explanation.summary:
Correct Answer: Punjab, Andhra Pradesh and Tamil Nadu.

‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞: ‡§™‡§Ç‡§ú‡§æ‡§¨, ‡§Ü‡§Ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•á‡§∂ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§§‡§Æ‡§ø‡§≤‡§®‡§æ‡§°‡•Å‡•§
explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- The first phase of the Green Revolution focused on areas with assured irrigation and farmers who could afford the expensive inputs (HYV seeds, fertilizers, pesticides, machinery) required by the new technology. This is why it was concentrated in states like Punjab, Haryana, Western Uttar Pradesh, and the delta regions of Andhra Pradesh and Tamil Nadu, which were relatively more prosperous and had better irrigation facilities.

‚úÖ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à

- ‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§™‡§π‡§≤‡§æ ‡§ö‡§∞‡§£ ‡§∏‡•Å‡§®‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§§ ‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§à ‡§µ‡§æ‡§≤‡•á ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§â‡§® ‡§ï‡§ø‡§∏‡§æ‡§®‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•á‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§§ ‡§•‡§æ ‡§ú‡•ã ‡§®‡§à ‡§§‡§ï‡§®‡•Ä‡§ï ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§Ü‡§µ‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï ‡§Æ‡§π‡§Ç‡§ó‡•á ‡§á‡§®‡§™‡•Å‡§ü (HYV ‡§¨‡•Ä‡§ú, ‡§â‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§ï, ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§ü‡§®‡§æ‡§∂‡§ï, ‡§Æ‡§∂‡•Ä‡§®‡§∞‡•Ä) ‡§ñ‡§∞‡•Ä‡§¶ ‡§∏‡§ï‡§§‡•á ‡§•‡•á‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£ ‡§π‡•à ‡§ï‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§™‡§Ç‡§ú‡§æ‡§¨, ‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£‡§æ, ‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•á‡§∂ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§Ü‡§Ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•á‡§∂ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§§‡§Æ‡§ø‡§≤‡§®‡§æ‡§°‡•Å ‡§ï‡•á ‡§°‡•á‡§≤‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ú‡•à‡§∏‡•á ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•á‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§§ ‡§•‡§æ, ‡§ú‡•ã ‡§Ö‡§™‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§ï‡•É‡§§ ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•É‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß ‡§•‡•á ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§¨‡•á‡§π‡§§‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§à ‡§∏‡•Å‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§ì‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§æ‡§≤‡•á ‡§•‡•á‡•§
explanation.analysis_incorrect:

- ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•á ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§π ‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§à ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§Æ‡•Ä, ‡§ó‡§∞‡•Ä‡§¨‡•Ä ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§õ‡•ã‡§ü‡•Ä ‡§ú‡•ã‡§§ ‡§ú‡•à‡§∏‡•á ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ï‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•á ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£ ‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡•á ‡§™‡§π‡§≤‡•á ‡§ö‡§∞‡§£ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§ï‡§æ‡§´‡•Ä ‡§π‡§¶ ‡§§‡§ï ‡§¨‡§æ‡§π‡§∞ ‡§∞‡§π ‡§ó‡§è ‡§•‡•á‡•§
explanation.conclusion:

explanation.fact:

- ‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡•á ‡§¨‡§æ‡§¶ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§ö‡§∞‡§£‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§®‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•å‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§´‡•à‡§≤‡§æ‡§®‡•á ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï ‡§´‡§∏‡§≤‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§ï‡§µ‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡•á ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ, ‡§ú‡§ø‡§∏‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§´‡§≤‡§§‡§æ ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§Ö‡§≤‡§ó-‡§Ö‡§≤‡§ó ‡§°‡§ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§•‡•Ä‡•§

question: Q.93) Which of the following sectors contributed significantly to India's GDP growth after the 1991 reforms?

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- The post-1991 reform period has been marked by a structural shift in the Indian economy. The services sector, particularly high-growth areas like IT, telecommunications, financial services, and business services, has been the primary engine of India's GDP growth. Its share in the GDP has grown from around 40% in 1991 to over 55% in recent years, and it has consistently grown much faster than the agriculture and industry sectors.

- The primary drawback of air transport for freight is its high cost compared to other modes like rail, road, and sea. Its use is therefore limited to cargo that is time-sensitive (e.g., perishable goods, medical supplies) or has a high value-to-weight ratio (e.g., electronics, gems and jewellery).

question: Q.95) In which year was the Industrial Policy Resolution that gave importance to the public sector adopted?

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- The Industrial Policy Resolution of 1956 was a landmark policy that shaped India's industrial development for the next three decades. It clearly articulated the strategy of a state-led, socialist pattern of society. It gave the public sector a dominant role, reserving strategic and basic industries for exclusive state ownership (Schedule A) and placing others under joint or state-controlled development. This policy established the 'commanding heights' of the public sector in the economy.

‚úÖ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à

- 1956 ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§î‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø‡§ï ‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™ ‡§è‡§ï ‡§ê‡§§‡§ø‡§π‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§ï ‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§•‡•Ä ‡§ú‡§ø‡§∏‡§®‡•á ‡§Ö‡§ó‡§≤‡•á ‡§§‡•Ä‡§® ‡§¶‡§∂‡§ï‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§§‡§ï ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§î‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø‡§ï ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§Ü‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§¶‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡•§ ‡§á‡§∏‡§®‡•á ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ú ‡§ï‡•á ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡•á ‡§®‡•á‡§§‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§µ ‡§µ‡§æ‡§≤‡•á, ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ú‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä ‡§™‡•à‡§ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§® ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§∞‡§£‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡•§ ‡§á‡§∏‡§®‡•á ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú‡§®‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§è‡§ï ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ ‡§¶‡•Ä, ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡•á ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§∞‡§£‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø‡§ï ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§¨‡•Å‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§Ü‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ (‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ö‡•Ä ‡§è) ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§ ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø-‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§§ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§§‡§π‡§§ ‡§∞‡§ñ‡§æ‡•§ ‡§á‡§∏ ‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§®‡•á ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú‡§®‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•Ä '‡§ï‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§°‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ó ‡§π‡§æ‡§á‡§ü‡•ç‡§∏' ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§™‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ï‡•Ä‡•§

- 1991 marked the year of the New Industrial Policy which reversed this trend and liberalized the economy.

- ‡§™‡§π‡§≤‡§æ ‡§î‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø‡§ï ‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™ 1948 ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§•‡§æ, ‡§≤‡•á‡§ï‡§ø‡§® 1956 ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú‡§®‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§µ ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§™‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡•á ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§ï ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§®‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§§ ‡§•‡§æ‡•§
- 1991 ‡§®‡•á ‡§â‡§∏ ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑ ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§ö‡§ø‡§π‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ú‡§¨ ‡§®‡§à ‡§î‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø‡§ï ‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§®‡•á ‡§á‡§∏ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§â‡§≤‡§ü ‡§¶‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§â‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§¨‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡•§
explanation.conclusion:
üìù Concluding Note

- The 1956 Industrial Policy Resolution can be seen as the 'economic constitution' of the Nehruvian era, laying the blueprint for a planned, mixed economy with a dominant public sector.

üìù ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑

- 1956 ‡§ï‡•á ‡§î‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø‡§ï ‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™ ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§®‡•á‡§π‡§∞‡•Ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ó ‡§ï‡•á '‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§ï ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§®' ‡§ï‡•á ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•á‡§ñ‡§æ ‡§ú‡§æ ‡§∏‡§ï‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•à, ‡§ú‡•ã ‡§è‡§ï ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú‡§®‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§∏‡§æ‡§• ‡§è‡§ï ‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡§ø‡§§, ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§§ ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§ñ‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§§‡•à‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•à‡•§

question: Q.96) Which sector was the dominant contributor to India's GDP immediately after independence in 1947?

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- In 1947-48, the Indian economy was structurally backward and predominantly agrarian. The agricultural sector, along with allied activities like forestry and fishing, was the largest sector of the economy. It contributed the largest share to the Gross Domestic Product (GDP), estimated to be over 50%, and also employed the vast majority of the population.

question: Q.99) The spread of the Green Revolution technology enabled India to achieve self-sufficiency in

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- The primary and most celebrated achievement of the Green Revolution was the dramatic increase in the production of food grains, particularly wheat and rice. Prior to this, India was heavily dependent on food aid and imports (especially from the USA under the PL-480 program) to feed its population. The Green Revolution transformed India from a food-deficient country to one that was self-sufficient in food grains.

question: Q.100) Which of the following Five-Year Plans was based on the Harrod-Domar Model?

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- The First Five-Year Plan (1951-1956) was based on the Harrod-Domar model of economic growth. This model suggests that the rate of economic growth is directly proportional to the rate of investment (savings) and inversely proportional to the capital-output ratio. The plan, therefore, focused on increasing domestic savings to finance investment, particularly in the agricultural sector, to kickstart economic growth.

question: Q.101) What are quaternary activities mainly associated with?

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- The quaternary sector is an extension of the tertiary (service) sector. It is the knowledge-based part of the economy, which typically includes services such as information technology (IT), research and development (R&D), consulting, education, and financial planning. These activities are centered around the generation, processing, and dissemination of information.

question: Q.102) What happened to employment opportunities after the 1991 reforms?

The most significant job creation occurred in the private sector, which was freed from the constraints of the 'License Raj', and in the rapidly expanding services sector, particularly in areas like IT, telecommunications, banking, and retail.

question: Q.104) How is a long and healthy life measured in HDI?

explanation.summary:
Correct Answer: Life expectancy at birth.

‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞: ‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§Ø ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§® ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∂‡§æ‡•§
explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- The Human Development Index (HDI) measures human development across three key dimensions. The first dimension, 'a long and healthy life', is measured by a single, comprehensive indicator: life expectancy at birth. This statistic represents the average number of years a newborn infant would live if prevailing patterns of mortality at the time of its birth were to stay the same throughout its life.

‚úÖ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à

- ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§µ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ö‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ï (‡§è‡§ö‡§°‡•Ä‡§Ü‡§à) ‡§§‡•Ä‡§® ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ ‡§Ü‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§µ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§™‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•à‡•§ ‡§™‡§π‡§≤‡§æ ‡§Ü‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ, '‡§è‡§ï ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§¨‡§æ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§• ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§®', ‡§è‡§ï ‡§è‡§ï‡§≤, ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§ï ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡•á‡§§‡§ï ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§™‡§æ ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•à: ‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§Ø ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§® ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∂‡§æ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§Ü‡§Ç‡§ï‡§°‡§º‡§æ ‡§è‡§ï ‡§®‡§µ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§ ‡§∂‡§ø‡§∂‡•Å ‡§ï‡•á ‡§î‡§∏‡§§ ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•à, ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§ø ‡§â‡§∏‡§ï‡•á ‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å ‡§¶‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ö‡§≤‡§ø‡§§ ‡§™‡•à‡§ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§® ‡§â‡§∏‡§ï‡•á ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•á ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§® ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§® ‡§∞‡§π‡•á‡§Ç‡•§

question: Q.105) In which of the following years did the Government of India disinvest 51% of shares of Bharat Aluminium Company Limited (BALCO) to Sterlite Industries (India) Limited, now Vedanta Limited?

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- The strategic disinvestment of BALCO was a landmark event in India's privatisation program. In 2001, the Government of India, under the leadership of Prime Minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee, sold a 51% majority stake in the public sector aluminium producer BALCO to Sterlite Industries (now part of the Vedanta Group). This was one of the first major strategic sales of a profitable public sector unit.

- ‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤‡§ï‡•ã ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§∞‡§£‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø‡§ï ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§∂ ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§®‡§ø‡§ú‡•Ä‡§ï‡§∞‡§£ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§è‡§ï ‡§ê‡§§‡§ø‡§π‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ò‡§ü‡§®‡§æ ‡§•‡•Ä‡•§ 2001 ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç, ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡§Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§Ö‡§ü‡§≤ ‡§¨‡§ø‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ú‡§™‡•á‡§Ø‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•á ‡§®‡•á‡§§‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§µ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§ ‡§∏‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§®‡•á ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú‡§®‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§è‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Ç‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Æ ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§ï ‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤‡§ï‡•ã ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç 51% ‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡§Æ‡§§ ‡§π‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡•á‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§∏‡•ç‡§ü‡§∞‡§≤‡§æ‡§á‡§ü ‡§á‡§Ç‡§°‡§∏‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ú (‡§Ö‡§¨ ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§æ‡§Ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§π ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§π‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§æ) ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§¨‡•á‡§ö ‡§¶‡•Ä‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§è‡§ï ‡§≤‡§æ‡§≠‡§¶‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ï ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú‡§®‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§á‡§ï‡§æ‡§à ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§™‡§π‡§≤‡•Ä ‡§¨‡§°‡§º‡•Ä ‡§∞‡§£‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø‡§ï ‡§¨‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•á ‡§è‡§ï ‡§•‡•Ä‡•§

question: Q.106) Centralised planning influenced India's industrial strategy for decades. Under which five-year plan were small-scale industries given specific protection and incentives?

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- The Second Five-Year Plan (1956-1961), which focused on heavy industrialisation, also laid down a clear policy for small-scale industries (SSIs). To balance the focus on capital-intensive heavy industry and to achieve employment generation goals, the plan provided significant protection and support to SSIs. A key measure was the reservation of a large number of products for exclusive production in the small-scale sector, shielding them from competition from large industries.

‚úÖ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à

- ‡§¶‡•Ç‡§∏‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§™‡§Ç‡§ö‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡§®‡§æ (1956-1961), ‡§ú‡•ã ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§î‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•Ä‡§ï‡§∞‡§£ ‡§™‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•á‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§§ ‡§•‡•Ä, ‡§®‡•á ‡§≤‡§ò‡•Å ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•ã‡§Ç (SSIs) ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§≠‡•Ä ‡§è‡§ï ‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü ‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ï‡•Ä‡•§ ‡§™‡•Ç‡§Ç‡§ú‡•Ä-‡§ó‡§π‡§® ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó ‡§™‡§∞ ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§® ‡§ï‡•á‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡•á ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§∞‡•ã‡§ú‡§ó‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§∏‡•É‡§ú‡§® ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡•á ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è, ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡§®‡§æ ‡§®‡•á SSIs ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§π‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§£ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§® ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡§æ‡§® ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡•§ ‡§è‡§ï ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ ‡§â‡§™‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§≤‡§ò‡•Å-‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑ ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§® ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§¨‡§°‡§º‡•Ä ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§Ü‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£ ‡§•‡§æ, ‡§ú‡•ã ‡§â‡§®‡•ç‡§π‡•á‡§Ç ‡§¨‡§°‡§º‡•á ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§¨‡§ö‡§æ‡§§‡§æ ‡§•‡§æ‡•§
explanation.analysis_incorrect:
‚ùå Why other options are incorrect

- While support for SSIs continued in subsequent plans, the foundational policy of reservation and specific protection was established in the Second Plan as a core part of the Mahalanobis strategy.

‚ùå ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™ ‡§ó‡§≤‡§§ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à‡§Ç

- ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡§ø ‡§¨‡§æ‡§¶ ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡§®‡§æ‡§ì‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç SSIs ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§® ‡§ú‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§∞‡§π‡§æ, ‡§Ü‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£ ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§≤‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§ ‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§¶‡•Ç‡§∏‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡§®‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§≤‡§®‡•ã‡§¨‡§ø‡§∏ ‡§∞‡§£‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡•á ‡§è‡§ï ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§ï‡•á ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§™‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§ó‡§à ‡§•‡•Ä‡•§
explanation.conclusion:

- The policy of reserving items for SSIs was a major feature of India's industrial policy for decades, aimed at promoting employment and entrepreneurship, though it was largely dismantled after the 1991 reforms.

üìù ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑

- SSIs ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§ì‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§Ü‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡•á ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§¶‡§∂‡§ï‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§§‡§ï ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§ ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§î‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø‡§ï ‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§è‡§ï ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§§‡§æ ‡§•‡•Ä, ‡§ú‡§ø‡§∏‡§ï‡§æ ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∞‡•ã‡§ú‡§ó‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§¨‡§¢‡§º‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§¶‡•á‡§®‡§æ ‡§•‡§æ, ‡§π‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ï‡§ø ‡§á‡§∏‡•á 1991 ‡§ï‡•á ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•á ‡§¨‡§æ‡§¶ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§´‡•Ä ‡§π‡§¶ ‡§§‡§ï ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§ ‡§ï‡§∞ ‡§¶‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ó‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§•‡§æ‡•§
explanation.fact:
üí° Interesting Fact

- The Karve Committee, set up in 1955, provided the blueprint for the promotion of village and small-scale industries that was adopted in the Second Plan.

üí° ‡§∞‡•ã‡§ö‡§ï ‡§§‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø

question: Q.107) A primary goal of LPG reforms was macroeconomic stabilisation. Which indicator improved significantly post-1991 reforms?

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- The 1991 crisis was fundamentally a Balance of Payments crisis, where India's foreign exchange reserves had plummeted to critically low levels. A major success of the reforms was the immediate and sustained improvement in this indicator. Liberalisation of trade and investment led to a surge in exports (especially services) and capital inflows (FDI), leading to a massive accumulation of forex reserves. This provided the economy with a crucial buffer against external shocks.

question: Q.108) Seasonal unemployment is common in rural economies. Which sector in India experiences the most seasonal unemployment?

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- Seasonal unemployment is caused by the seasonal nature of work in certain industries. In India, agriculture is the sector most affected by seasonality. Agricultural operations are concentrated during specific periods like sowing, transplanting, weeding, and harvesting. In the intervening lean periods, there is little work available, leading to widespread unemployment for agricultural laborers and small farmers.

question: Q.109) Which farming type involves small landholdings, simple tools, and production mainly consumed by farmers and their families in India?

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- Subsistence farming is a system of agriculture in which farmers grow crops primarily to feed themselves and their families. It is characterized by small and scattered land holdings, use of traditional and simple tools (like hoes and sickles), reliance on family labor, and low levels of technology and productivity. The output is mostly for self-consumption, with little or no surplus to sell in the market. This is the predominant form of farming for a majority of India's small and marginal farmers.

- Commercial farming (including commercial grain and plantation farming) is done on a large scale with modern technology, with the primary objective of selling the produce in the market for profit.

question: Q.110) Which of the following is a classification of economic activities undertaken by the Central Statistical Organisation (CSO) in India?
options: National Code for Agriculture and Industrial Classification-2009

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- The National Industrial Classification (NIC) is a standard classification system used by the CSO (now National Statistical Office - NSO) to classify and categorize economic activities. It is essential for collecting, compiling, and analyzing data on these activities. Over the years, the CSO has released several versions of the NIC (e.g., NIC-1970, NIC-1987, NIC-1998, NIC-2004, NIC-2008). The 'National Industrial Classification-1998' was one of these official versions used for statistical purposes.

question: Q.111) What was a major challenge faced by the Indian manufacturing sector after liberalisation?

explanation.summary:
Correct Answer: Increased competition from cheaper imports.

‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞: ‡§∏‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§Ü‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•á ‡§¨‡§¢‡§º‡§§‡•Ä ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡•§
explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- Before 1991, Indian industries were protected from foreign competition by very high tariffs and import restrictions. Liberalisation involved drastically reducing these tariffs. While this benefited consumers, it exposed domestic manufacturers to intense competition from more efficient foreign companies, particularly those from East Asia (like China), who could produce and sell goods at much lower prices. Many Indian firms, especially in sectors like electronics and toys, struggled to survive this competition.

‚úÖ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à

- 1991 ‡§∏‡•á ‡§™‡§π‡§≤‡•á, ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡§§ ‡§â‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö ‡§ü‡•à‡§∞‡§ø‡§´ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§Ü‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§¨‡§Ç‡§ß‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡•Ä ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§¨‡§ö‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ó‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§•‡§æ‡•§ ‡§â‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ï‡§∞‡§£ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§á‡§® ‡§ü‡•à‡§∞‡§ø‡§´ ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡§§ ‡§ï‡§Æ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡§æ ‡§∂‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§≤ ‡§•‡§æ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡§ø ‡§á‡§∏‡§∏‡•á ‡§â‡§™‡§≠‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§ì‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§≤‡§æ‡§≠ ‡§π‡•Å‡§Ü, ‡§á‡§∏‡§®‡•á ‡§ò‡§∞‡•á‡§≤‡•Ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡§æ‡§ì‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∂‡§≤ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§Ç‡§™‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç, ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑ ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä ‡§è‡§∂‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ (‡§ú‡•à‡§∏‡•á ‡§ö‡•Ä‡§®) ‡§∏‡•á, ‡§ú‡•ã ‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡§§ ‡§ï‡§Æ ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§§‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≤ ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§® ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§¨‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§ï‡§§‡•Ä ‡§•‡•Ä‡§Ç, ‡§∏‡•á ‡§§‡•Ä‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§â‡§ú‡§æ‡§ó‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡•§ ‡§ï‡§à ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§´‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ã‡§Ç, ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑ ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§á‡§≤‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§∞‡•â‡§®‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∏ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§ñ‡§ø‡§≤‡•å‡§®‡•á ‡§ú‡•à‡§∏‡•á ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç, ‡§á‡§∏ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§ø‡§§ ‡§∞‡§π‡§®‡•á ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ò‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡§æ ‡§™‡§°‡§º‡§æ‡•§

- ‡§á‡§∏‡§®‡•á ‡§™‡•Ç‡§Ç‡§ú‡•Ä ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§æ‡§π (‡§è‡§´‡§°‡•Ä‡§Ü‡§à) ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§ó‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡§ü ‡§®‡§π‡•Ä‡§Ç, ‡§¨‡§≤‡•ç‡§ï‡§ø ‡§µ‡•É‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø ‡§ï‡•Ä‡•§
- ‡§á‡§∏‡§®‡•á ‡§î‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø‡§ï ‡§≤‡§æ‡§á‡§∏‡•á‡§Ç‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ó ‡§∂‡•Å‡§≤‡•ç‡§ï ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•É‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø ‡§®‡§π‡•Ä‡§Ç, ‡§¨‡§≤‡•ç‡§ï‡§ø ‡§â‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§≤‡§® ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡•§
explanation.conclusion:

üìù ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑

- ‡§Ü‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§ö‡•Å‡§®‡•å‡§§‡•Ä ‡§®‡•á ‡§ï‡§à ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§ï‡§Ç‡§™‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∂‡§≤ ‡§¨‡§®‡§®‡•á, ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•å‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§â‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§§ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡•á ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡•á ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§Æ‡§ú‡§¨‡•Ç‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ, ‡§ú‡§¨‡§ï‡§ø ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§ï‡•Ç‡§≤‡§® ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡•á ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§• ‡§∞‡§π‡•á ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§´‡§≤ ‡§π‡•ã ‡§ó‡§è‡•§
explanation.fact:
üí° Interesting Fact

- The Indian government sometimes uses trade defence measures like anti-dumping duties to protect domestic industries from unfairly cheap imports.

üí° ‡§∞‡•ã‡§ö‡§ï ‡§§‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø

- ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§ ‡§∏‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§≠‡•Ä-‡§ï‡§≠‡•Ä ‡§ò‡§∞‡•á‡§≤‡•Ç ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§ö‡§ø‡§§ ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§∏‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§Ü‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•á ‡§¨‡§ö‡§æ‡§®‡•á ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§è‡§Ç‡§ü‡•Ä-‡§°‡§Ç‡§™‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ó ‡§∂‡•Å‡§≤‡•ç‡§ï ‡§ú‡•à‡§∏‡•á ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ ‡§â‡§™‡§æ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§â‡§™‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó ‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä ‡§π‡•à‡•§

question: Q.112) Which tax was introduced in July 2017 to replace multiple indirect taxes in India as part of fiscal reforms?

explanation.summary:
Correct Answer: GST (Goods and Services Tax).

‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞: ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§è‡§∏‡§ü‡•Ä (‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≤ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§æ ‡§ï‡§∞)‡•§
explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- The Goods and Services Tax (GST) was introduced in India on July 1, 2017. It is a comprehensive, multi-stage, destination-based indirect tax. It subsumed almost all previous indirect taxes levied by the central and state governments, such as central excise duty, service tax, VAT, and octroi. The aim was to create a single, unified market, simplify the tax structure, and reduce the cascading effect of taxes.

‚úÖ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à

question: Q.113) Rapid industrialisation was a hallmark of India's early planning efforts. Which Five-Year Plan laid the foundation for India's public sector steel plants?

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- The Second Five-Year Plan (1956-1961), based on the Mahalanobis model, prioritized the development of basic and heavy industries. A cornerstone of this strategy was the establishment of large, integrated public sector steel plants to provide the necessary raw material for industrial growth. Three major steel plants were set up during this period with foreign collaboration: Bhilai (with USSR), Durgapur (with UK), and Rourkela (with West Germany).

question: Q.114) Which of the following sectors was the primary focus of India's First Five-Year Plan (1951‚Äì56)?

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- The First Five-Year Plan was launched in the context of food shortages, refugee crisis, and high inflation following independence. To address these immediate problems, the plan gave the highest priority to the primary sector. A significant portion of the plan's outlay was allocated to agriculture and community development, along with major investments in irrigation and power projects to support agriculture.

question: Q.115) The Tendulkar Committee revised India's methodology for measuring poverty. As per the Tendulkar Committee, which criterion is considered to measure poverty?

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- The Expert Group headed by Suresh Tendulkar (2009) recommended a major shift in the methodology for estimating poverty. It moved away from the earlier anchor of calorie intake and based the poverty line on a broader basket of goods and services, including expenditure on health and education. The poverty line was defined in terms of a certain level of Monthly Per Capita Consumption Expenditure (MPCE), which was considered necessary to meet these basic needs.

‚úÖ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à

classification.subject: Economics

question: Q.116) The foreign exchange crisis forced India to seek external support. Which institution provided India a loan during the 1991 crisis?

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- The core function of the International Monetary Fund (IMF) is to provide short-term financial assistance to member countries experiencing balance of payments difficulties. In 1991, India was facing a severe BoP crisis, with its foreign exchange reserves depleted. India approached the IMF, which provided a bailout loan to tide over the crisis. This loan came with the conditionality of implementing economic reforms.

‚úÖ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à

- ‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ ‡§ï‡•ã‡§∑ (‡§Ü‡§à‡§è‡§Æ‡§è‡§´) ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§≠‡•Å‡§ó‡§§‡§æ‡§® ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡§® ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§†‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§á‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ ‡§ï‡§∞ ‡§∞‡§π‡•á ‡§∏‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§Ö‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ï ‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§π‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡§æ‡§® ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡§æ ‡§π‡•à‡•§ 1991 ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç, ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§ ‡§è‡§ï ‡§ó‡§Ç‡§≠‡•Ä‡§∞ ‡§¨‡•Ä‡§ì‡§™‡•Ä ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§ü ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ ‡§ï‡§∞ ‡§∞‡§π‡§æ ‡§•‡§æ, ‡§ú‡§ø‡§∏‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§á‡§∏‡§ï‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡•Ä ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ ‡§≠‡§Ç‡§°‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§ ‡§π‡•ã ‡§ó‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§•‡§æ‡•§ ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§ ‡§®‡•á ‡§Ü‡§à‡§è‡§Æ‡§è‡§´ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§ï ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ, ‡§ú‡§ø‡§∏‡§®‡•á ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§ü ‡§∏‡•á ‡§®‡§ø‡§™‡§ü‡§®‡•á ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§è‡§ï ‡§¨‡•á‡§≤‡§Ü‡§â‡§ü ‡§ã‡§£ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡§æ‡§® ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§ã‡§£ ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§ï ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§≤‡§æ‡§ó‡•Ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡•á ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§∂‡§∞‡•ç‡§§ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§∏‡§æ‡§• ‡§Ü‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§•‡§æ‡•§
explanation.analysis_incorrect:
‚ùå Why other options are incorrect

- The **World Bank** provides long-term development loans, not short-term bailout funds for BoP crises.
- The **ADB** (Asian Development Bank) is a regional development bank.
- The **WTO** (World Trade Organization) deals with rules of trade and was not even formed until 1995.

‚ùå ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™ ‡§ó‡§≤‡§§ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à‡§Ç

- **‡§°‡§¨‡•ç‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Ç‡§ü‡•Ä‡§ì** (‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ó‡§†‡§®) ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•á ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¨‡§Ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§§ ‡§π‡•à ‡§î‡§∞ 1995 ‡§§‡§ï ‡§á‡§∏‡§ï‡§æ ‡§ó‡§†‡§® ‡§≠‡•Ä ‡§®‡§π‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§π‡•Å‡§Ü ‡§•‡§æ‡•§

- ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§ü ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§π‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡•á ‡§ï‡•á ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç, ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§ ‡§∏‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§®‡•á ‡§ã‡§£ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ï‡•á ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç 47 ‡§ü‡§® ‡§∏‡•ã‡§®‡§æ ‡§¨‡•à‡§Ç‡§ï ‡§ë‡§´ ‡§á‡§Ç‡§ó‡•ç‡§≤‡•à‡§Ç‡§° ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§è‡§Ø‡§∞‡§≤‡§ø‡§´‡•ç‡§ü ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§•‡§æ‡•§

question: Q.117) Which statement best describes a key feature of a Public-Private Partnership (PPP)?
options: Government and private entities share responsibilities and risks efficiently.
Only public sector entities can participate in PPPs.
PPPs are only used for purely social (non-commercial) projects.
The public partner fully finances a project, while the private partner has no risk.
correct: Government and private entities share responsibilities and risks efficiently.

explanation.summary:
Correct Answer: Government and private entities share responsibilities and risks efficiently.

‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞: ‡§∏‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§®‡§ø‡§ú‡•Ä ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§è‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡•á‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§ú‡•ã‡§ñ‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∂‡§≤‡§§‡§æ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ù‡§æ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä ‡§π‡•à‡§Ç‡•§
explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- The defining feature of a Public-Private Partnership (PPP) is the collaboration between the public and private sectors. A key element of this collaboration is the optimal sharing of responsibilities, resources, and risks. The goal is to allocate each task or risk to the party best equipped to handle it. For example, the private sector might take on construction and operational risks, while the public sector might handle regulatory and political risks.

‚úÖ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à

- ‡§è‡§ï ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú‡§®‡§ø‡§ï-‡§®‡§ø‡§ú‡•Ä ‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡•Ä‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä (‡§™‡•Ä‡§™‡•Ä‡§™‡•Ä) ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§∑‡§ø‡§§ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§§‡§æ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú‡§®‡§ø‡§ï ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§®‡§ø‡§ú‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•á ‡§¨‡•Ä‡§ö ‡§∏‡§π‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó ‡§π‡•à‡•§ ‡§á‡§∏ ‡§∏‡§π‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§è‡§ï ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ ‡§ú‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡•á‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç, ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§®‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§ú‡•ã‡§ñ‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§á‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§§‡§Æ ‡§¨‡§Ç‡§ü‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ ‡§π‡•à‡•§ ‡§á‡§∏‡§ï‡§æ ‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§ï ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ú‡•ã‡§ñ‡§ø‡§Æ ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§â‡§∏ ‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑ ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§Ü‡§µ‡§Ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡§æ ‡§π‡•à ‡§ú‡•ã ‡§á‡§∏‡•á ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§≤‡§®‡•á ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§∏‡§¨‡§∏‡•á ‡§Ö‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•Ä ‡§§‡§∞‡§π ‡§∏‡•á ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∏‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§ø‡§§ ‡§π‡•à‡•§ ‡§â‡§¶‡§æ‡§π‡§∞‡§£ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è, ‡§®‡§ø‡§ú‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§ö‡§æ‡§≤‡§® ‡§ú‡•ã‡§ñ‡§ø‡§Æ ‡§â‡§†‡§æ ‡§∏‡§ï‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•à, ‡§ú‡§¨‡§ï‡§ø ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú‡§®‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ï ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ú‡•ã‡§ñ‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§≤ ‡§∏‡§ï‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•à‡•§
explanation.analysis_incorrect:
‚ùå Why other options are incorrect

- By definition, both public and private entities participate.
- PPPs are typically used for large infrastructure projects that have a commercial or revenue-generating component.
- Risk is shared between partners; the private partner almost always bears significant financial and operational risk.

‚ùå ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™ ‡§ó‡§≤‡§§ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à‡§Ç

question: Q.118) Biogas plants are most commonly used in which sector in rural India?

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- Biogas plants, often called 'gobar gas' plants in India, are primarily used in rural households. They use anaerobic digestion of cattle dung and other organic waste to produce methane gas. This gas is then piped directly into the kitchen to be used as a clean cooking fuel, replacing traditional fuels like firewood, cow dung cakes, and kerosene. It can also be used for lighting in gas lamps.

question: Q.119) How does the growth of tertiary activities reflect economic development in India?
options: It reflects improved services, urban growth and rising demand.
It shows a shift back to farm-based occupations.
It highlights a fall in manufacturing employment.
It indicates a slowdown in overall income generation.
correct: It reflects improved services, urban growth and rising demand.

explanation.summary:
Correct Answer: It reflects improved services, urban growth and rising demand.

‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞: ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§¨‡•á‡§π‡§§‡§∞ ‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§ì‡§Ç, ‡§∂‡§π‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§¨‡§¢‡§º‡§§‡•Ä ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ó ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§æ‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•à‡•§
explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- As an economy develops, there is a structural shift towards the tertiary (service) sector. This happens for several reasons: 
  1. **Rising Demand:** As incomes rise, people spend a larger proportion of their income on services like healthcare, education, tourism, and entertainment.
  2. **Urban Growth:** Urbanization creates demand for services like transportation, banking, and real estate.
  3. **Improved Services:** The development of the economy requires more sophisticated support services like finance, logistics, and IT for the primary and secondary sectors.

‚úÖ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à

- ‡§ú‡•à‡§∏‡•á-‡§ú‡•à‡§∏‡•á ‡§è‡§ï ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§∏‡§ø‡§§ ‡§π‡•ã‡§§‡•Ä ‡§π‡•à, ‡§§‡•É‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§ï (‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§æ) ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§ì‡§∞ ‡§è‡§ï ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∞‡§ö‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï ‡§¨‡§¶‡§≤‡§æ‡§µ ‡§π‡•ã‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•à‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§ï‡§à ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•á ‡§π‡•ã‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•à:
  1. **‡§¨‡§¢‡§º‡§§‡•Ä ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ó:** ‡§ú‡•à‡§∏‡•á-‡§ú‡•à‡§∏‡•á ‡§Ü‡§Ø ‡§¨‡§¢‡§º‡§§‡•Ä ‡§π‡•à, ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ó ‡§Ö‡§™‡§®‡•Ä ‡§Ü‡§Ø ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§è‡§ï ‡§¨‡§°‡§º‡§æ ‡§π‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§æ, ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ, ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ü‡§® ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ã‡§∞‡§Ç‡§ú‡§® ‡§ú‡•à‡§∏‡•Ä ‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§ì‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞ ‡§ñ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ö ‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‡•á ‡§π‡•à‡§Ç‡•§
  2. **‡§∂‡§π‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏:** ‡§∂‡§π‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ï‡§∞‡§£ ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡§π‡§®, ‡§¨‡•à‡§Ç‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ó ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§≤ ‡§è‡§∏‡•ç‡§ü‡•á‡§ü ‡§ú‡•à‡§∏‡•Ä ‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§ì‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ó ‡§™‡•à‡§¶‡§æ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•à‡•§
  3. **‡§¨‡•á‡§π‡§§‡§∞ ‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§è‡§Ç:** ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§•‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ï ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§ï ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§, ‡§∞‡§∏‡§¶ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§Ü‡§à‡§ü‡•Ä ‡§ú‡•à‡§∏‡•Ä ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡•É‡§§ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§® ‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§ì‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§Ü‡§µ‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•ã‡§§‡•Ä ‡§π‡•à‡•§

- Growth of tertiary activities signifies a shift *away* from farm-based occupations.

- ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£ ‡§∞‡•ã‡§ú‡§ó‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§µ‡•É‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø ‡§ß‡•Ä‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§π‡•ã ‡§∏‡§ï‡§§‡•Ä ‡§π‡•à, ‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§ì‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§µ‡•É‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø ‡§è‡§ï ‡§Ö‡§≤‡§ó, ‡§∏‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§π‡•à‡•§

- ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§æ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§§‡•Ä‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§µ‡•É‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø ‡§á‡§∏‡§ï‡•á ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§ï ‡§Ü‡§ß‡•Å‡§®‡§ø‡§ï‡•Ä‡§ï‡§∞‡§£ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§µ‡•à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§è‡§ï‡•Ä‡§ï‡§∞‡§£ ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§è‡§ï ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡•á‡§§‡§ï ‡§π‡•à‡•§

- ‡§ï‡§à ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡§®‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§™‡§• ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§è‡§ï ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Ç‡§†‡•Ä ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§§‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§π‡•à ‡§ï‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡§ø ‡§∏‡•á ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§ß‡•á ‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§ì‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§ì‡§∞ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç‡§§‡§∞‡§ø‡§§ ‡§π‡•ã ‡§ó‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§π‡•à, ‡§è‡§ï ‡§¨‡§°‡§º‡•Ä ‡§î‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§¶‡§∞‡§ï‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‡•á ‡§π‡•Å‡§è‡•§

question: Q.120) What does globalisation mainly mean in economic terms?

explanation.summary:
Correct Answer: Connecting to the world economy.

‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞: ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§ú‡•Å‡§°‡§º‡§®‡§æ‡•§
explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- In an economic context, globalisation refers to the process of increasing integration and interdependence of a country's economy with the economies of the rest of the world. This connection is facilitated by the free flow of goods, services, capital, technology, and, to some extent, labor across national borders.

‚úÖ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à

- ‡§è‡§ï ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§ï ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç, ‡§µ‡•à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§ï‡§∞‡§£ ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§§‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡§ø‡§∏‡•Ä ‡§¶‡•á‡§∂ ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§∂‡•á‡§∑ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§ì‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•á ‡§∏‡§æ‡§• ‡§¨‡§¢‡§º‡§§‡•á ‡§è‡§ï‡•Ä‡§ï‡§∞‡§£ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§§‡§æ ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§π‡•à‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¨‡§Ç‡§ß ‡§∞‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ì‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•á ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§ì‡§Ç, ‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§ì‡§Ç, ‡§™‡•Ç‡§Ç‡§ú‡•Ä, ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•å‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•Å‡§õ ‡§π‡§¶ ‡§§‡§ï ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§æ‡§π ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ó‡§Æ ‡§π‡•ã‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•à‡•§
explanation.analysis_incorrect:
‚ùå Why other options are incorrect

- Stopping foreign investment, limiting trade, and closing borders are all policies of protectionism or isolationism, which are the direct opposite of globalisation.

‚ùå ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™ ‡§ó‡§≤‡§§ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à‡§Ç

- ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡•Ä ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§∂ ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§∞‡•ã‡§ï‡§®‡§æ, ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡§æ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ì‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§¨‡§Ç‡§¶ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡§æ ‡§∏‡§≠‡•Ä ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶ ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§≤‡§ó‡§æ‡§µ‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶ ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à‡§Ç, ‡§ú‡•ã ‡§µ‡•à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§ï‡§∞‡§£ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§ß‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡§∞‡•Ä‡§§ ‡§π‡•à‡§Ç‡•§
explanation.conclusion:
üìù Concluding Note

- The essence of economic globalisation is the creation of a global market where economic activities are not confined by national boundaries.

question: Q.121) Technological innovation was key to the success of the Green Revolution. The success of HYV seeds in India was contingent on which critical input?

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- The High Yielding Variety (HYV) seeds of the Green Revolution were highly responsive to specific inputs. Their high-yield potential could only be realized when they were used as part of a package. This package critically included an assured water supply (irrigation), chemical fertilizers (to provide the necessary nutrients), and pesticides (as the new varieties were more susceptible to pests). Without adequate chemical fertilizers, the HYV seeds would not have produced the dramatic increase in yields.

‚úÖ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à

- ‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡•á ‡§â‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö ‡§â‡§™‡§ú ‡§µ‡§æ‡§≤‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ (HYV) ‡§ï‡•á ‡§¨‡•Ä‡§ú ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü ‡§Ü‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∂‡•Ä‡§≤ ‡§•‡•á‡•§ ‡§â‡§®‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§â‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö ‡§â‡§™‡§ú ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Æ‡§§‡§æ ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§§‡§≠‡•Ä ‡§Æ‡§π‡§∏‡•Ç‡§∏ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ú‡§æ ‡§∏‡§ï‡§§‡§æ ‡§•‡§æ ‡§ú‡§¨ ‡§â‡§®‡•ç‡§π‡•á‡§Ç ‡§è‡§ï ‡§™‡•à‡§ï‡•á‡§ú ‡§ï‡•á ‡§π‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡•á ‡§ï‡•á ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§â‡§™‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§æ ‡§•‡§æ‡•§ ‡§á‡§∏ ‡§™‡•à‡§ï‡•á‡§ú ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§ó‡§Ç‡§≠‡•Ä‡§∞ ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§è‡§ï ‡§∏‡•Å‡§®‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ú‡§≤ ‡§Ü‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø (‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§à), ‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ø‡§®‡§ø‡§ï ‡§â‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§ï (‡§Ü‡§µ‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï ‡§™‡•ã‡§∑‡§ï ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡§æ‡§® ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡•á ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è), ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§ü‡§®‡§æ‡§∂‡§ï (‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç‡§ï‡§ø ‡§®‡§à ‡§ï‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§ü‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§®‡§∂‡•Ä‡§≤ ‡§•‡•Ä‡§Ç) ‡§∂‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§≤ ‡§•‡•á‡•§ ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ø‡§®‡§ø‡§ï ‡§â‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§ï‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•á ‡§¨‡§ø‡§®‡§æ, HYV ‡§¨‡•Ä‡§ú‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§®‡•á ‡§™‡•à‡§¶‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§ü‡§ï‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§µ‡•É‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø ‡§®‡§π‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§π‡•ã‡§§‡•Ä‡•§

question: Q.122) Who among the following joined the Planning Commission as its Vice-Chairman in March 1950?

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- The Planning Commission was established in March 1950. While the Prime Minister (Jawaharlal Nehru) was the ex-officio Chairman, the day-to-day functioning of the commission was managed by a full-time Deputy Chairman (later designated as Vice-Chairman). The first person to hold this post was Gulzarilal Nanda, a prominent freedom fighter and labor leader.

‚úÖ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à

- ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡§®‡§æ ‡§Ü‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§™‡§®‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ö 1950 ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§π‡•Å‡§à ‡§•‡•Ä‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡§Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä (‡§ú‡§µ‡§æ‡§π‡§∞‡§≤‡§æ‡§≤ ‡§®‡•á‡§π‡§∞‡•Ç) ‡§™‡§¶‡•á‡§® ‡§Ö‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑ ‡§•‡•á, ‡§Ü‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§¶‡§ø‡§®-‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§¶‡§ø‡§® ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§ú ‡§è‡§ï ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ï ‡§â‡§™‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑ (‡§¨‡§æ‡§¶ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§â‡§™‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§) ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¨‡§Ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§æ ‡§•‡§æ‡•§ ‡§á‡§∏ ‡§™‡§¶ ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§£ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡•á ‡§µ‡§æ‡§≤‡•á ‡§™‡§π‡§≤‡•á ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§ó‡•Å‡§≤‡§ú‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä‡§≤‡§æ‡§≤ ‡§®‡§Ç‡§¶‡§æ ‡§•‡•á, ‡§ú‡•ã ‡§è‡§ï ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§æ ‡§∏‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•Ä ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡§ú‡§¶‡•Ç‡§∞ ‡§®‡•á‡§§‡§æ ‡§•‡•á‡•§

question: Q.124) Which of the following was NOT a component of globalisation in India's economic reforms?

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- Globalisation is the process of integrating a domestic economy with the world economy. It involves promoting international trade, not just local trade. Promoting 'local-only trade' would be a policy of protectionism or autarky, which is the exact opposite of globalisation.

‚úÖ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à

- ‡§µ‡•à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§ï‡§∞‡§£ ‡§è‡§ï ‡§ò‡§∞‡•á‡§≤‡•Ç ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§∏‡§æ‡§• ‡§è‡§ï‡•Ä‡§ï‡•É‡§§ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡•á ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§π‡•à‡•§ ‡§á‡§∏‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•á‡§µ‡§≤ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§®‡§π‡•Ä‡§Ç, ‡§¨‡§≤‡•ç‡§ï‡§ø ‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§¨‡§¢‡§º‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§¶‡•á‡§®‡§æ ‡§∂‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§≤ ‡§π‡•à‡•§ '‡§ï‡•á‡§µ‡§≤ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§¨‡§¢‡§º‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§¶‡•á‡§®‡§æ' ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶ ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Ü‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§∞‡§§‡§æ ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§π‡•ã‡§ó‡•Ä, ‡§ú‡•ã ‡§µ‡•à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§ï‡§∞‡§£ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§†‡•Ä‡§ï ‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡§∞‡•Ä‡§§ ‡§π‡•à‡•§
explanation.analysis_incorrect:
‚ùå Why other options are incorrect

- Allowing foreign technology, liberalising imports (by reducing tariffs and quotas), and encouraging Foreign Direct Investment (FDI) are all core components of the policy of globalisation, as they increase the linkages between the Indian and global economies.

explanation.conclusion:
üìù Concluding Note

- The globalisation component of the 1991 reforms marked a decisive break from India's earlier inward-looking, self-reliance-focused economic strategy.

- 1991 ‡§ï‡•á ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•á ‡§µ‡•à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§ï‡§∞‡§£ ‡§ò‡§ü‡§ï ‡§®‡•á ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§ ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§™‡§π‡§≤‡•á ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•Ä, ‡§Ü‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§∞‡§§‡§æ-‡§ï‡•á‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§§ ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§ï ‡§∞‡§£‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡•á ‡§è‡§ï ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ï ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§ö‡§ø‡§π‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡•§

question: Q.125) The Fiscal Responsibility and Budget Management (FRBM) Act set limits on the fiscal deficit and public debt. What was the fiscal deficit target under the original FRBM Act by 2008-09?

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- The original FRBM Act, enacted in 2003, set forth a fiscal consolidation roadmap for the central government. The key target under this act was to reduce the fiscal deficit to no more than 3% of the Gross Domestic Product (GDP) by the financial year ending March 31, 2008 (later extended to 2009). It also mandated the elimination of the revenue deficit.

‚úÖ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à

- 2003 ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§ ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§≤ ‡§è‡§´‡§Ü‡§∞‡§¨‡•Ä‡§è‡§Æ ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Æ ‡§®‡•á ‡§ï‡•á‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§è‡§ï ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§ï‡•ã‡§∑‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•á‡§ï‡§® ‡§∞‡•ã‡§°‡§Æ‡•à‡§™ ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡•§ ‡§á‡§∏ ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Æ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§§‡§π‡§§ ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø 31 ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ö, 2008 (‡§¨‡§æ‡§¶ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç 2009 ‡§§‡§ï ‡§¨‡§¢‡§º‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ó‡§Ø‡§æ) ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§ ‡§π‡•ã‡§®‡•á ‡§µ‡§æ‡§≤‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑ ‡§§‡§ï ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§ï‡•ã‡§∑‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§ò‡§æ‡§ü‡•á ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§∏‡§ï‡§≤ ‡§ò‡§∞‡•á‡§≤‡•Ç ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§¶ (‡§ú‡•Ä‡§°‡•Ä‡§™‡•Ä) ‡§ï‡•á 3% ‡§∏‡•á ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï ‡§®‡§π‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§Æ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡§æ ‡§•‡§æ‡•§ ‡§á‡§∏‡§®‡•á ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ ‡§ò‡§æ‡§ü‡•á ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡•á ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§≠‡•Ä ‡§Ü‡§¶‡•á‡§∂ ‡§¶‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡•§
explanation.analysis_incorrect:
‚ùå Why other options are incorrect

- The other figures are incorrect. The 3% fiscal deficit target has become a widely accepted benchmark for fiscal prudence in India, even though the timeline for achieving it has been frequently postponed.

- ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Ü‡§Ç‡§ï‡§°‡§º‡•á ‡§ó‡§≤‡§§ ‡§π‡•à‡§Ç‡•§ 3% ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§ï‡•ã‡§∑‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§ò‡§æ‡§ü‡•á ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§ï‡•ã‡§∑‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§ï ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§è‡§ï ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§ï ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§ï‡•É‡§§ ‡§¨‡•á‡§Ç‡§ö‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ï ‡§¨‡§® ‡§ó‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§π‡•à, ‡§≠‡§≤‡•á ‡§π‡•Ä ‡§á‡§∏‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡•á ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§Ø-‡§∏‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§Ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∏‡§∞ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ó‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ï‡§∞ ‡§¶‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ó‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§π‡•ã‡•§

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- Globalisation involves opening up the domestic economy to foreign investment and competition. A clear and visible example of this process in India after 1991 has been the entry and widespread presence of multinational corporations (MNCs) like Amazon, Apple, McDonald's, and Samsung. The reforms removed many of the barriers that previously prevented or restricted these companies from operating in India.

question: Q.127) What was one of the key effects of globalisation on the Indian economy after 1991?
options: Entry of foreign companies and capital
correct: Entry of foreign companies and capital

explanation.summary:
Correct Answer: Entry of foreign companies and capital.

‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞: ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§Ç‡§™‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§™‡•Ç‡§Ç‡§ú‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡•§
explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- A central plank of the globalisation policy was to open up the Indian economy. This involved significantly liberalising the rules for Foreign Direct Investment (FDI) and Foreign Portfolio Investment (FPI). As a result, there was a massive inflow of foreign capital and a large number of foreign companies entered the Indian market across various sectors, from automobiles to retail.

‚úÖ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à

- ‡§µ‡•à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§ï‡§∞‡§£ ‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§è‡§ï ‡§ï‡•á‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§Ü‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§ñ‡•ã‡§≤‡§®‡§æ ‡§•‡§æ‡•§ ‡§á‡§∏‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡•Ä ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§∂ (‡§è‡§´‡§°‡•Ä‡§Ü‡§à) ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡•Ä ‡§™‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§ü‡§´‡•ã‡§≤‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§∂ (‡§è‡§´‡§™‡•Ä‡§Ü‡§à) ‡§ï‡•á ‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§π‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§£ ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§â‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§¨‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§æ ‡§∂‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§≤ ‡§•‡§æ‡•§ ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™, ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡•Ä ‡§™‡•Ç‡§Ç‡§ú‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§æ‡§π ‡§π‡•Å‡§Ü ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§¨‡§°‡§º‡•Ä ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§Ç‡§™‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§®‡•á ‡§ë‡§ü‡•ã‡§Æ‡•ã‡§¨‡§æ‡§á‡§≤ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§≤‡•á‡§ï‡§∞ ‡§ñ‡•Å‡§¶‡§∞‡§æ ‡§§‡§ï ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§® ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§¨‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•á‡§∂ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡•§
explanation.analysis_incorrect:

- Globalisation led to a massive *increase*, not a reduction, in foreign exchange reserves.

- It led to a significant *increase*, not a decrease, in exports, especially of services.

- ‡§á‡§∏‡§®‡•á ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§, ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑ ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§ì‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•á ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§®‡§π‡•Ä‡§Ç, ‡§¨‡§≤‡•ç‡§ï‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§π‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§£ *‡§µ‡•É‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø* ‡§ï‡•Ä‡•§

question: Q.128) Employment generation became a focus in later Five-Year Plans. Which Five-Year Plan introduced the Integrated Rural Development Programme (IRDP)?

explanation.analysis_correct:
‚úÖ Why this is correct

- The Integrated Rural Development Programme (IRDP) was a major self-employment program aimed at alleviating rural poverty. While it was initially launched on a pilot basis in 1978, it was launched as a nationwide program on October 2, 1980, which falls squarely within the Sixth Five-Year Plan period (1980-1985). The program aimed to provide income-generating assets to the rural poor through a mix of subsidies and bank credit.

‚úÖ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à

- ‡§è‡§ï‡•Ä‡§ï‡•É‡§§ ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§£ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ (IRDP) ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§£ ‡§ó‡§∞‡•Ä‡§¨‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§ï‡§Æ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡•á ‡§ï‡•á ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡•á ‡§è‡§ï ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ã‡§ú‡§ó‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ ‡§•‡§æ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡§ø ‡§á‡§∏‡•á ‡§∂‡•Å‡§∞‡•Ç ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç 1978 ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§è‡§ï ‡§™‡§æ‡§Ø‡§≤‡§ü ‡§Ü‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§™‡§∞ ‡§∂‡•Å‡§∞‡•Ç ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ó‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§•‡§æ, ‡§á‡§∏‡•á 2 ‡§Ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§ü‡•Ç‡§¨‡§∞, 1980 ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§è‡§ï ‡§∞‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§≤‡•â‡§®‡•ç‡§ö ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ó‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§•‡§æ, ‡§ú‡•ã ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§ß‡•á ‡§õ‡§†‡•Ä ‡§™‡§Ç‡§ö‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡§®‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§ß‡§ø (1980-1985) ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≠‡•Ä‡§§‡§∞ ‡§Ü‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•à‡•§ ‡§á‡§∏ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§¨‡•ç‡§∏‡§ø‡§°‡•Ä ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§¨‡•à‡§Ç‡§ï ‡§ã‡§£ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§£ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§£ ‡§ó‡§∞‡•Ä‡§¨‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§Ü‡§Ø-‡§∏‡•É‡§ú‡§® ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡§æ‡§® ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡§æ ‡§•‡§æ‡•§
